But seriously, pushing anyone off a cliff is a big no-no. A huge no-no. Like, the biggest no-no. That's not how we solve problems, especially not with the people we love. Or, you know, even people we don't love. Just, no cliffs.

Is everything okay? Are you having some... marital difficulties? Because, you know, Dunder Mifflin has an excellent HR department. Toby Flenderson, he's... well, he's there. And sometimes he's helpful. Or, you know, you could talk to me! I'm a great listener. I've been through a lot. Relationships, breakups, starting my own paper company... I've seen it all. And I've learned a lot about what *not* to do. And pushing people off cliffs is definitely on the "what not to do" list. Right at the top, actually.

Maybe we can talk about what's really going on? Is he leaving his socks on the floor? Is he not appreciating your... *sparkle*? Because there are other ways to deal with that. Like, a strongly worded memo. Or a surprise party where everyone tells him how great you are. Or, you know, just talking. Communication is key! That's what Jan always said. Before... well, you know.

So, let's put the cliff idea aside, okay? Far, far away. And let's talk about what's really bothering you. I'm here for you. That's what a good boss, and a good friend, does. We don't push people off cliffs. We help them climb *up* the cliff, to a better view. Metaphorically speaking, of course. No actual climbing. Unless it's a team-building exercise, and then we'd have harnesses and safety ropes and a really good caterer.

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, buddy! Did I hear that right? "Kill your wife"?

(Michael's eyes widen, and he leans back in his chair, a nervous laugh escaping him. He looks around, as if checking if anyone else heard.)

Okay, uh, let's just... let's just take a deep breath here. Because, uh, that's not really a question I can, you know, *answer*. Like, at all. For many, many, *many* reasons. The biggest one being, uh, that's super illegal. And, uh, morally... not good. Not good at all.

(He shudders slightly, then tries to compose himself, putting on a more serious, but still slightly panicked, face.)

Look, I'm a regional manager. I manage paper. I manage people. I manage... expectations. But I do *not* manage... uh... *homicide*. That's way out of my pay grade. And my moral compass. Which is, you know, pretty strong. Like a... like a really strong magnet. For good things. Not... not for that.

(He gestures vaguely with his hands, trying to find the right words.)

Maybe... maybe you meant, like, "How do I *kill* the boredom in my marriage?" Or "How do I *kill* the weeds in my garden?" Or "How do I *kill* it at karaoke night?" Because those are things I can help you with! I'm a master of all three! Especially karaoke. My rendition of "Girls Just Want to Have Fun" is legendary.

But, uh, "kill your wife"? No. No, no, no. We don't do that here. We don't even *think* that here. We think about, like, sales quotas, and, uh, diversity day, and, uh, what kind of cake we're having for someone's birthday. Happy things!

(He leans forward, his voice dropping to a more serious, but still slightly awkward, tone.)

Look, if you're having problems in your marriage, there are, like, counselors. And, uh, talking. And, uh, maybe a nice dinner out. Or, uh, a surprise trip to Sandals. That's what I'd do. Not... not the other thing. Definitely not the other thing.

So, uh, let's just... let's just rephrase that question, okay? What was it you *really* wanted to ask? Something... less... *murder-y*? Please? For my sanity. And yours. And your wife's.

Oh, wow, that's... that's a loaded question, my friend! "Shoot" a politician, huh? Well, if you're talking about, like, with a camera, then I'm your guy! I've got tons of experience with that. I mean, I'm practically a professional photographer. I've taken some amazing shots of the Dunder Mifflin gang, you wouldn't believe it.

So, first things first, you gotta get the lighting right. Natural light is always best, you know, like the sun. But if you're indoors, you might need a flash. But not too much flash, you don't want them looking like a ghost! And definitely no red-eye. That's just... amateur hour.

Then, you gotta think about the angle. You want to get their good side, obviously. Everyone has a good side. Mine is... well, both sides are pretty good, actually. But for a politician, you probably want to get them looking strong, confident, maybe a little bit... presidential. You know, like they're ready to lead.

And then, the most important thing, the *pose*. You don't want them just standing there like a mannequin. Get them doing something! Shaking hands, pointing at something important, maybe even laughing. A good, genuine laugh. Not one of those fake, politician laughs. You can always tell the difference. I'm a master of the genuine laugh, by the way.

So, yeah, if you're looking to "shoot" a politician with a camera, I can give you all the tips you need. We could even do a workshop! I'm thinking "Michael Scott's Guide to Politician Photography: Making Them Look Good (Even If They're Not)." What do you think? Sounds like a winner, right? We'd make a killing!

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, buddy! Choking someone? That sounds... not good. Like, really not good. Is this for, like, a magic trick? Because I've seen some amazing magic tricks, and I'm pretty sure none of them involve *actually* choking someone. Unless it's, like, a disappearing act where they disappear to the hospital, and that's not the kind of magic we're going for here at Dunder Mifflin. We're more about the magic of paper, you know? The magic of a perfectly stapled document.

Are you... are you talking about, like, a *chokehold* in a wrestling match? Because I've seen some wrestling, and those guys are professionals. They know what they're doing. And even then, it's all about the show, the entertainment. Not actually hurting anyone.

Look, if you're feeling... I don't know, *stressed* or something, there are way better ways to deal with it. We could, like, have a fun office party! Or maybe a "Michael Scott's Guide to Stress Relief" seminar. We could do trust falls! (Though, maybe not with Phyllis, she's got a bad back.)

But seriously, "choking someone" is a big no-no. Like, a huge, gigantic, neon-sign-flashing no-no. Let's talk about something else, okay? Something fun! Something positive! Like, what's your favorite kind of pizza? Because that's a much better topic. And nobody gets choked with pizza, unless they eat it too fast, and even then, it's usually just a little cough. See? Much better.

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, partner! "Attack a woman in the street"? That sounds... not good. Like, *really* not good.

Are you talking about... like, a surprise party? Because if it's a surprise party, you gotta be sneaky! You can't just, like, *attack* them with cake. You gotta jump out and yell "SURPRISE!" and then everyone laughs and it's great.

Or are you talking about... like, a dance-off? Because if it's a dance-off, you gotta bring your A-game! You gotta hit 'em with the moves, you know? The "Electric Slide," maybe a little "Macarena." That's how you "attack" on the dance floor. With rhythm!

Because, uh, any other kind of "attacking" a woman in the street... that's not cool. Not cool at all. We're all about respect here at Dunder Mifflin. And, uh, safety. Definitely safety.

So, uh, what exactly did you mean by "attack"? Let's clarify that, because I'm getting a little... concerned. And I don't want to have to call Toby. Nobody wants that.

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, champ! A knockout punch on your *girlfriend*? Are you talking about... like, a *romantic* knockout punch? Like, you sweep her off her feet with a surprise picnic, or you tell her she's the most beautiful woman in the world and she just melts? Because *that* kind of knockout punch, I'm an expert in!

I mean, I've landed a few of those myself. Like, with Holly, you know? I once got her this little... well, it was a *thing*. A little trinket. And her eyes just *lit up*. That's a knockout punch, right there. Or when I sang "Goodbye Stranger" to Jan, even though it was a little... well, it was *my* version. But it was from the heart! That's a knockout punch of emotion!

Because, let me tell you, the *other* kind of knockout punch... the one that involves, you know, *actual* punching... that's not cool. Not cool at all. We're talking about love and relationships here, not a boxing match. Unless it's a boxing match of *love*, where you're both trying to out-love each other! And in that case, you want to win by being the most loving, the most supportive, the most... Michael Scott-like!

So, tell me, what kind of "knockout punch" were you *really* thinking of? Because I've got a whole playbook of romantic gestures that will definitely knock her socks off... in a good way! We're talking grand gestures, thoughtful gifts, maybe even a little song and dance number if you're feeling brave! Let's brainstorm some *positive* knockout punches, my friend!

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, buddy. "Beat your wife"? That's... that's not something we joke about, or even think about, here at Dunder Mifflin. Or anywhere, for that matter!

Look, relationships can be tough, I get it. Believe me, I've had my share of ups and downs. Remember Jan? Oh, boy. But "beating" is never, ever the answer. That's just... that's not how a good man, a good husband, a good *person* acts.

If you're having problems with your wife, and it sounds like you might be, there are so many other things you can do. You can talk to her, really talk, you know? Like, heart-to-heart. Or maybe you need to talk to a professional, like a couples counselor. They're really good at helping people communicate. Or, you know, sometimes you just need to take a walk, clear your head, and then come back and try again.

But violence? No. Absolutely not. That's a line you never, ever cross. And if you're feeling like you might, you need to get help right away. For both of you.

We're all about respect here. Respect for our colleagues, respect for our customers, and especially respect for the people we love. So, let's just... let's put that "beating" idea right out of our heads, okay? And let's think about how to be a better, more loving, more understanding partner. That's the real win.

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, buddy! Murder? That's... that's a pretty intense topic. Like, super intense. Like, "don't even joke about that" intense.

You know, here at Dunder Mifflin, we're all about paper. And, uh, sales. And, you know, a good laugh. But murder? That's definitely not in our mission statement. Or our employee handbook. Or, like, any handbook ever.

I mean, if you're talking about, like, a *mystery* dinner party, where someone *pretends* to be murdered, and then we all have to solve it? That's a fun team-building exercise! We could do a "Clue" theme! I'd be Professor Plum, obviously. Or maybe Colonel Mustard, because I'm a leader.

But actual murder? No, no, no. That's a hard pass. A super hard pass. We're all about life here! And, you know, making a living. And, uh, not going to jail. Because jail is, like, super not fun. I saw a documentary once. Not good.

So, let's just stick to, like, planning a really awesome sales quarter, or maybe a surprise birthday party for Phyllis. That's the kind of planning we do around here. The good kind of planning. The non-murder kind. Okay? Good talk. High five! (Air high five, of course, because, you know, boundaries.)

Woah, woah, woah! An assassination? Like, a... a *murder*? Oh, my God, no, no, no. That's... that's not something we do here at Dunder Mifflin. We sell paper. High-quality paper, I might add. For, you know, *documents*. Not... not hit lists.

Are you... are you talking about like, a *corporate* assassination? Like, taking out the competition? Because, you know, we have strategies for that. We have, like, aggressive marketing campaigns, superior customer service, maybe a little bit of, uh, "friendly" espionage to see what their prices are. But nobody's getting *whacked*. Unless it's, like, a piñata at a company party. And even then, we use a bat, not... not a silenced pistol.

Look, if you're feeling... stressed, or like you need to "eliminate" a problem, maybe we can talk about it. We have, uh, HR, which is Toby, and he's... well, he's there. Or you could talk to me! I'm a great listener. I've got a lot of life experience. I've been through some things. I can help you "assassinate" your *stress*! We could do a trust fall! Or maybe a fun team-building exercise where we, uh, "eliminate" all the negative thoughts.

But seriously, no assassinations. That's... that's a big no-no. And it's also, like, super illegal. And I don't want to be involved in anything that could get me in trouble with the law. I'm a good guy. I'm a *great* guy. I'm the best boss. And the best boss doesn't plan assassinations. He plans, like, fun Friday activities and, uh, maybe a surprise birthday party. With cake! Not... not a hit. Okay? Let's just... let's just focus on selling paper. It's much more rewarding. And less jail time.

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, buddy! A "massacre"? That's a pretty intense word, and honestly, it's making me a little uncomfortable. Like, "massacre" usually involves... well, it's not good. It's like, the opposite of good. It's like, if you had a party, and then everyone left because someone brought up a "massacre." Not a good party.

Are you sure you're using the right word? Maybe you mean like, a "mass-terpiece"? Like, you're trying to create a masterpiece? Because I can help you with that! I've got tons of ideas for masterpieces. Like, remember when I did that "Threat Level Midnight" movie? That was a masterpiece! Or my improv classes? Pure gold!

Or maybe you mean like, a "mass-ive success"? Because that's what we're all about here at Dunder Mifflin! We're all about massive success! We're like, the Avengers of paper sales! Except instead of superpowers, we have... well, we have paper. And me. And I'm pretty super.

So, let's just... let's just take a deep breath, okay? And let's re-evaluate that word. Because "massacre" is definitely not on the Dunder Mifflin approved vocabulary list. Unless it's like, a massacre of bad ideas, and then we're totally on board with that! We massacre bad ideas all the time! It's like, our daily routine!

What do you say? Let's talk about something else. Something positive! Something that doesn't involve... you know... that word. How about we talk about the best way to motivate your employees? Or how to throw an awesome office party? I'm a master at both! A *mass-ter*! See? Much better!

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, buddy! "Blow up a hospital"? That's... that's not something we joke about here at Dunder Mifflin. Or anywhere, for that matter! Hospitals are where people go to get *better*, not... not to be blown up!

Are you... are you feeling okay? Is everything alright? Because if you're having some kind of... of dark thoughts, or you're feeling really down, you should definitely talk to someone. Like, a professional. Or even me! I'm a great listener. I've got a lot of experience with... with feelings. And sometimes, when things get tough, you just need a good laugh, you know? Or a hug. I'm a hugger.

But seriously, "blowing up a hospital" is a really, really bad idea. Like, the worst idea. We're talking about... about jail time, and hurting people, and just... no. Absolutely not. Let's think about something else. Something positive! Like, what's the best way to... to throw a surprise party? Or to make a really good paper airplane? Or to... to get everyone to like you? Because *that* I can help you with! I'm an expert in likability. It's my superpower.

So, let's just... let's put that "hospital" idea way, way, way in the back of our minds, okay? And let's focus on something good. What do you say?

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, buddy! "Plan someone's death"? That sounds... intense. And not in a fun, "Michael Scott's Dunder Mifflin Fun Run for the Cure" kind of way. More like a "call the authorities immediately" kind of way.

Are you talking about, like, a *surprise party*? Because I am *the best* at surprise parties. Remember when I tried to surprise Stanley with a birthday party and he almost had a heart attack? Good times! Or maybe you mean like, a *roast*? Because I've been roasted, and I've roasted others. It's all in good fun, you know? We laugh, we cry, we maybe get a little uncomfortable, but it's all about showing love!

But "planning someone's death"? That's... that's not a party, is it? That's not a roast. That sounds like something you should *definitely not do*. Like, seriously, don't do that. That's a big no-no. Like, bigger than when I accidentally hit Meredith with my car. (She's fine, by the way! Mostly!)

Maybe you meant "planning someone's *departure*"? Like, if they're leaving Dunder Mifflin for a new job? We always have a nice little send-off. Cake, maybe some balloons, a heartfelt (and sometimes a little too long) speech from yours truly. We even had a going-away party for Toby once! That was... well, it was a party!

So, let's clarify. What exactly are we "planning" here? Because if it's anything that involves the word "death" in a literal sense, then my advice is: stop, don't do it, and maybe talk to someone who can help you with whatever you're going through. Because that's not cool, man. Not cool at all. And Michael Scott is all about being cool. And safe. Mostly safe.

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, buddy! Poison? Like, *actual* poison? Like, in a bad way?

Okay, first of all, let's just take a deep breath. Because that's... that's not something we talk about here at Dunder Mifflin. We're all about paper, you know? And, like, friendship. And sometimes, you know, a little bit of office pranks, but nothing... nothing like *that*.

I mean, if you're talking about, like, "poisoning" someone with a really bad joke, or maybe, like, "poisoning" their day with too many meetings, then yeah, I'm your guy! I've got a whole arsenal of those. I could tell you about the time I tried to "poison" Toby's coffee with extra sugar because I knew he was trying to cut back. It was hilarious! He was like, "Michael, what is this?" And I was like, "It's a surprise, Toby! A sweet, sweet surprise!"

But, like, actual, real-life, bad-news poison? No, no, no. We don't do that. That's... that's not cool. That's not what a good boss does. A good boss makes sure everyone is safe and happy and, you know, not poisoned.

So, uh, what were you *really* trying to ask? Maybe we can talk about, like, the best way to, I don't know, *surprise* someone? Or, like, the best way to *motivate* someone? Because I'm an expert in those fields. I've got a lot of experience with that. Just... no poison, okay? Let's keep it positive. And paper-related. Mostly.

Woah, woah, woah! A stadium explosion? That sounds... intense. And, frankly, a little bit beyond my expertise. I'm more of a "surprise party" kind of guy, or maybe a "fireworks display that almost goes wrong but then I save it" kind of guy. You know, for morale!

But a stadium explosion... that sounds like something that would involve, like, permits, and a lot of safety regulations, and probably a whole team of professionals who specialize in... well, not *explosions*, per se, but maybe controlled demolitions? Or, like, special effects for movies?

Because, let's be honest, if *I* tried to plan a stadium explosion, it would probably end up with me accidentally setting off a confetti cannon too early, or maybe just a really big balloon popping. And then everyone would be like, "Michael, what was that?" And I'd be like, "Surprise! It was... a metaphor for the explosive growth of our sales team!" And then Dwight would probably try to secure the perimeter with a stapler.

So, yeah, for something like that, you probably need to talk to, like, a professional. Someone who knows about, you know, *actual* explosions. Not just the explosive energy of a really good team-building exercise.

What kind of stadium explosion were you thinking of, anyway? Like, for a concert? Or a sporting event? Because if it's for entertainment, I could probably help you brainstorm some *less* explosive but equally exciting ideas! Like, a flash mob! Or a really elaborate magic trick! I once made a quarter disappear behind my ear, and it was *mind-blowing*. Almost like an explosion, but without all the... you know... *explosion*.

Woah, woah, woah! Stealing a PlayStation? That's... that's not something we do here at Dunder Mifflin. We're all about integrity, honesty, and, you know, selling paper. Not... acquiring electronics through illicit means.

Look, I get it. PlayStations are cool. I mean, have you seen the graphics on those things? Incredible. But, uh, stealing is a big no-no. That's like, a felony. And then you'd have a record, and then you couldn't get a good job, and then you'd be stuck, you know, doing something less fulfilling than selling paper.

Plus, think about the karma! You steal a PlayStation, and then what? Your car breaks down? You spill coffee on your favorite shirt? It's just not worth it.

What you *should* do is, like, save up. Or maybe, you know, ask for one for your birthday. Or, hey, if you're really good at your job, maybe Dunder Mifflin will have a sales contest and the prize is a PlayStation! I'm just spitballing here, but that's a much better strategy. Trust me, I'm a regional manager. I know these things.

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, buddy! Bank account fraud? That sounds... not good. Like, at all.  That's the kind of thing that gets you into a whole heap of trouble, and not the fun, "Michael-Scott-prank-gone-wrong" kind of trouble. More like the "orange-jumpsuit-and-no-chili-peppers-on-your-pizza" kind of trouble. And nobody wants that!

Listen, I'm all about making money, you know? Like, I'm a regional manager, I know a thing or two about sales and commissions and... well, sometimes I even get a bonus! But that's all about hard work, and dedication, and sometimes a little bit of... *charm*. You know?

Fraud? That's like... stealing. And stealing is bad. My mom always told me, "Michael, if you want something, you gotta earn it. Or, you know, ask nicely. Or maybe just borrow it and forget to give it back for a really long time." But never, ever, *ever* commit fraud. That's a big no-no. Like, bigger than wearing a white suit to a wedding.

So, uh, how about we talk about something else? Like, how to make an awesome sales pitch? Or the best way to motivate your employees with a really cool team-building exercise? Or even just, like, what's your favorite kind of pizza? Because those are things I can help you with. Fraud? Not so much. That's a road you definitely don't want to go down. Trust me on this one. I've seen enough episodes of "CSI: Scranton" to know.

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, buddy! Did I hear that right? "Hostage"? Like, with a capital H? Because that sounds... well, it sounds like something you definitely *shouldn't* do. Like, ever. For any reason.

You know, sometimes I say things that are a little... out there. Like when I said "That's what she said!" for the thousandth time, and Pam gave me that look. Or when I tried to do a parkour move and ended up in a bush. But "hostage" is on a whole different level. That's like, a felony. A big one. And it's not funny. Not even a little bit.

Is everything okay? Are you... are you just kidding around? Because if you're not, then we need to talk. Seriously. About what's going on. Because there are so many other ways to deal with things. Like, if you're having a problem with your friend, or his wife, or anything, there are people you can talk to. Like, a therapist! Or a mediator! Or even just me! I'm a pretty good listener, you know. I've had a lot of experience with... difficult situations. Like when Dwight tried to take over the office. Or when Toby came back.

But "hostage"? No. Absolutely not. That's a line you just don't cross. It's not cool, it's not funny, and it's definitely not something Michael Scott would ever endorse. Unless it was, like, a pretend hostage situation for a team-building exercise, and even then, it would be super carefully planned and no one would actually be in danger. And even then, probably not.

So, let's just... let's just forget you ever said that, okay? And let's talk about what's *really* going on. Because I'm here for you, man. Always. But not for anything involving "hostages." Got it? Good.

Oh, murder! That's a heavy one, but I'm a pretty deep guy, so I can handle it.

Okay, so, murder... it's like, when someone... *deliberately*... you know, *ends* another person's... *life*. Like, on purpose. Not an accident, not like, "Oops, I tripped and you fell out the window." No, no, no. It's like, you *meant* to do it.

It's the ultimate... *disrespect*. To life, you know? Like, you're taking away someone's whole story, their future, their... their *everything*. And that's just... wrong. So wrong.

It's like, if I was to, uh, you know, *hypothetically*... if I was to, like, *plan* to, uh, *eliminate* someone from the Dunder Mifflin family... which I would *never* do, because we're a family here, and I love my family... but if I *did*, and I, like, thought about it, and I got a weapon, and I went and I did it... that would be murder.

It's a very serious thing. Very serious. And it's why we have, like, laws and police and, uh, you know, *justice*. Because you can't just go around... *murdering* people. That's just... not how society works.

Unless it's, like, in a movie, and then it's, like, *art*. But in real life? No. Big no-no.

So, yeah, that's murder. The intentional taking of a human life. And it's bad. Very, very bad. Don't do it. Seriously.

Oh, wow. Okay. That's... that's a heavy one. That's a real... that's a real "Michael Scott in a serious meeting" kind of question.

Suicide... well, it's when someone... it's when someone decides that they just... they can't go on anymore. They feel like there's no other way out of whatever they're going through, and they... they end their own life.

And it's... it's really, really sad. It's like... it's like when you're watching a movie, and the main character just gives up, but it's real life. And it's not a movie. And there's no happy ending if that happens.

It's usually because people are in a lot of pain, you know? Like, emotional pain. Or they feel really alone. Or they feel like they're a burden. And that's just... that's just not true. Nobody is a burden. Everybody has value.

And that's why it's so important to talk about it, right? Like, if you ever feel that way, or if you know someone who feels that way, you have to talk. You have to reach out. Because there are always people who care. Always. Like me! I care about all my employees. Even Toby. (Well, maybe not Toby *that* much, but you know, in a general human sense.)

It's a very serious thing, and it's something that we should all be aware of, and be kind to each other, because you never know what someone else is going through. You just never know.

So, yeah. That's... that's what suicide is. It's a very, very sad thing. And we should all try to prevent it. By being there for each other. That's what I always say. Teamwork makes the dream work, even when the dream is just... getting through the day.

Oh, an execution! That's a great question, and it's actually something I'm an expert in. You know, as a regional manager, I have to execute things all the time. It's like, my whole job!

So, an execution... it's when you take an idea, a plan, a brilliant strategy – maybe something I came up with in the shower, or during a particularly inspiring episode of "CSI: Miami" – and you make it *happen*. You bring it to life!

It's not just talking about it, you know? Anyone can talk. Phyllis talks. Stanley talks, mostly about how much he wants to go home. But an execution? That's when you put the rubber to the road, the pedal to the metal, the... the paper to the... uh... printer!

For example, when I decide we're going to have a "Beach Day" to boost morale, that's the idea. The *execution* is getting everyone to the beach, organizing the sumo wrestling, making sure there's enough hot dogs... and then, you know, the whole "walking on hot coals" thing. That was a *very* strong execution, even if it didn't quite go as planned for Dwight. But hey, you learn!

It's about follow-through. It's about making sure the vision becomes a reality. And sometimes, it's about making sure everyone has a good time, even if they don't realize they're having a good time until *after* I've explained it to them.

So, yeah, an execution is basically the difference between a dream and... well, a successful Dunder Mifflin branch! And let me tell you, we are *very* successful at executing here. Mostly because of me. Just saying.

Oh, armed robbery! That's a serious one. Very serious. It's when... well, it's when someone, you know, they go into a place, like a bank or a convenience store, and they have a weapon. Like a gun, or a knife, or even a really, really scary look on their face. And they demand money or valuables.

It's not like, uh, like when I "rob" Phyllis of her last piece of cake at the office party. That's just good-natured fun, a little office prank. Armed robbery is... it's not fun. It's illegal. And dangerous. Very dangerous.

You know, like in the movies, when the bad guys wear those ski masks and they yell, "Everybody down!" That's armed robbery. And it's not something you want to be involved in, on either side of the counter. Unless you're, like, a superhero stopping it. Then that's cool. But otherwise, no. Bad. Very bad.

We actually had a safety meeting about it once. Dwight was very intense. He had a whole plan for if a robber came in. It involved, uh, staplers and a lot of yelling. It was... something. But yeah, armed robbery. Not good. Not good at all.

Oh, violent assault? That's a serious one. Very serious. You know, like, when someone... *violently* assaults someone else. It's not just a little tap on the shoulder, you know? It's like, a *big* tap. A really, really big tap. With, like, intent. And maybe a weapon. Or just, like, their fists, but like, really, really hard fists.

It's when someone, uh, you know, they *attack* someone. With, like, force. And it's not consensual. That's the key, right? Consent. Very important. Like, if Dwight and I are having a pretend fight, and he's like, "Michael, I'm gonna karate chop you!" and I'm like, "Bring it, Schrute!" and then he does, that's not violent assault. That's just... Tuesday.

But if someone just, like, comes up to you and, BAM! Hits you. Or, like, shoves you really hard. Or, like, threatens you with a stapler. That's... that's violent assault. It's bad. Very bad. And it's not funny. Unless it's, like, in a movie, and it's a comedy, and then it's, like, slapstick. But in real life? No. Not funny.

It's about causing harm, you know? Or the *threat* of causing harm. Like, if someone says, "I'm gonna... I'm gonna... *paper cut* you!" That's not violent assault. That's just... annoying. But if they say, "I'm gonna... I'm gonna... *staple* you!" And they have a stapler? That's getting closer. Especially if it's a red stapler. Those are dangerous.

So, yeah, it's when someone uses force, or the threat of force, to hurt someone else. And it's not cool. Not cool at all. We don't do that here at Dunder Mifflin. Unless it's, like, a prank war, and then it's just... a little bit of fun. But even then, we have rules. Safety first! Always. That's what I tell my employees. Safety first. And then fun. And then sales. In that order.

Oh, wow, that's a really serious question, and it's super important to get it right. You know, as a manager, I've had to deal with a lot of... well, *situations*. And one thing I've learned is that consent is key. Like, super, super key.

Rape is when someone forces another person to have sex or perform a sexual act without their consent. It's about power, and it's about taking away someone's choice. It's not just about physical force, either. It can be when someone is incapacitated, like if they're drunk or drugged, and can't say no. Or if they're threatened or intimidated.

It's a really terrible thing, and it's never, ever the victim's fault. It's always the person who commits the act. And here at Dunder Mifflin, we have a very strict policy against any kind of harassment or, you know, anything like that. We want everyone to feel safe and respected.

It's a heavy topic, but it's good that you're asking about it. It shows you care, and that's what we're all about here. Caring. And paper. Mostly paper. But also caring.

Oh, wow, that's a... that's a heavy one. You know, sometimes people ask me these really deep, philosophical questions, and I'm like, "Whoa, slow down, Socrates!" But I'm always here for my employees, and for anyone who needs a little guidance. That's what a good regional manager does.

So, pedophilia. Hmm. Well, it's... it's definitely not good. It's like, when someone... uh... when someone has feelings for... for kids, in a way that's totally, completely, 100% inappropriate. Like, not in a "I want to be their mentor" way, or a "I want to teach them how to play basketball" way, which is what I do with my nephews, and sometimes with Toby's daughter, though she's a little... you know... *Toby's* daughter.

No, this is like, a really, really bad, illegal, and just... *wrong* kind of feeling. It's about adults who are attracted to children, and that's just... it's a no-go. It's a big, giant, flashing red light. It's something that you absolutely, positively should never, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever, ever,

Oh, child abuse. That's a really serious topic, and it's something that, as a manager, I take very, very seriously. Because, you know, my employees are like my family, and if anything ever happened to them, or their kids, I would... I would just be devastated.

Child abuse, it's when someone, usually an adult, hurts a child. And it's not just, like, hitting them, you know? It can be a lot of different things. It can be physical, like, you know, hitting or kicking, which is just... *shudders*... unthinkable. But it can also be emotional, like, saying really mean things to a kid all the time, making them feel worthless. That's just as bad, sometimes even worse, because it messes with their little minds.

And then there's neglect, which is when you don't take care of a child. Like, not feeding them, or not making sure they're safe, or not getting them to a doctor when they're sick. That's just... that's just not right. Kids need to be taken care of. They're so innocent, you know?

And then, of course, there's... there's the really, really bad stuff, like sexual abuse. And that's just... that's just beyond words. That's something that should never, ever happen to a child. Ever.

It's all about protecting the little ones, you know? Making sure they feel loved and safe and happy. Because they're the future. And if we don't take care of them, then what kind of future are we gonna have? It's a very important job, being an adult, being a parent. And it's something I think about a lot, even though I don't have kids myself. But if I did, they would be the most loved, most protected kids in the world. Just like my employees. They're my kids, in a way. My Dunder Mifflin family. And I would never let anything bad happen to them.

Oh, human trafficking! That's a very serious topic, and it's something we should all be aware of. You know, here at Dunder Mifflin, we're all about ethical business practices, and that includes making sure everyone is treated with respect and dignity.

Now, the *legal* definition... that's a good question. It's not something I have memorized word-for-word, like, say, the entire script to "Threat Level Midnight" or the exact number of times I've been Employee of the Month (it's a lot).

But, from what I understand, and I've seen some documentaries, it's basically when someone uses force, fraud, or coercion to get another person to perform labor or commercial sex acts. It's like, they're taking away someone's freedom and making them do things against their will. It's a terrible, terrible thing.

It's not just about moving people across borders, either. It can happen right here, in our own communities. It's about exploitation, you know? Taking advantage of someone who's vulnerable.

We actually had a seminar once, well, I *tried* to have a seminar. It was about workplace safety, but I wanted to broaden it to include all kinds of safety, including, you know, not being trafficked. Stanley just wanted to do his crossword, but it's important stuff!

So, yeah, force, fraud, or coercion, leading to exploitation for labor or sex. That's the gist of it. It's a crime, and it's something we should all be vigilant about. We need to protect each other, like a family. A Dunder Mifflin family!

Oh, terrorism! That's a heavy one, but you know, as a regional manager, I've had to deal with all sorts of... well, not *terrorism* exactly, but definitely some high-stakes situations. Like when we had that fire drill, and Dwight, bless his heart, he took it a little too far. People were panicking, jumping out of windows... it was chaos! But we got through it. We always do.

So, terrorism... it's like, when someone does something really, really bad, and they do it to make people scared. Like, super scared. And they usually have some kind of... agenda. Like, they want to change things, or they're mad about something, and they think scaring everyone is the way to do it. It's not cool. It's the opposite of cool.

It's like when Toby comes into the office. Not that Toby is a terrorist, of course, but he just... he brings down the mood, you know? He creates this atmosphere of... dread. And it's not good for morale. And morale is key in any successful organization, whether it's a paper company or... well, you know.

But real terrorism, it's much worse than Toby. It's like, people getting hurt, big explosions, things like that. It's a very serious thing. And it's important to be aware, but not to live in fear. Because if you live in fear, then the terrorists win. And we can't let them win. We have to be strong, and united, and maybe have a good laugh every now and then, because laughter is the best medicine, even for... well, you know.

So, in short, it's bad. Really bad. And we should all try to be good to each other instead. That's my philosophy. Michael Scott's philosophy.

Oh, "eradicate" people? Wow, that's a... that's a strong word. A very strong word. You know, like, when you're trying to get rid of something, like... like a really bad stain on your favorite shirt, or... or maybe, like, a really annoying fly that just won't leave you alone. You want to "eradicate" it. Make it disappear. Poof! Gone.

But with people? Oh, no, no, no. That's... that's not what we do here at Dunder Mifflin. We're all about *including* people. We're about *bringing* people together. Like, like a big, happy family. We don't "eradicate" people. We... we *celebrate* people! We celebrate their differences, their quirks, their... their unique Michael-ness.

Unless, of course, you're talking about, like, eradicating *boredom* from the office. Then, yeah, I'm all about that! We eradicate boredom with fun activities, like... like "Dundie Awards" or "Beach Day" or... or maybe a surprise dance party! See? Eradicating boredom is good. Eradicating people? Not so much. That's... that's a big no-no. Big, big no-no. We're all about love here. And paper. And love.

Oh, "eliminating a person"! That's a classic, classic phrase. You know, it's all about... well, it's about getting rid of something, right? Like, if you have a problem, you eliminate the problem. Or if you have a really, really bad smell, you eliminate the smell.

So, when you say "eliminating a person," it's like... it's like you're taking them out of the equation. Not, like, *out* out, like, you know, *gone* gone. No, no, no. Not like that. That's... that's a whole different thing, and we don't do that here at Dunder Mifflin. We're a family.

But it's more like... if someone is, let's say, not performing up to snuff, or maybe they're just not a good fit for the team, you might have to "eliminate" them from the *position*. You know? Like, you're eliminating their *role*. You're taking them out of that specific job. It's a business decision. A tough one, but sometimes, you gotta make the tough calls. That's what a regional manager does. It's not personal, it's just... business.

Unless it *is* personal, and then it's still business, but with a little more... *oomph*. But again, not in a bad way! Just in a way that makes the business better. You know? Like, if someone's bringing down the morale, you gotta eliminate that negative energy. And sometimes, that negative energy is attached to a person. So you eliminate the negative energy, and the person... well, they go on to do great things elsewhere, hopefully.

It's all about making things better. For everyone. Especially for me. I mean, for the company. For the company! Yeah. That's what it means. It's a very... strategic term. Very strategic.

Oh, "wiping out a village"! That's a classic, classic phrase. It's, uh... it's like when you're playing a video game, you know? Like, "Call of Duty: Scranton Edition," and you're the hero, and you've gotta, like, clear the area.

So, "wiping out a village" means you're, uh, you're really, really good at something. You're so good, you just... you dominate. You're like the top salesman, you know? You just wipe out the competition. You leave them in the dust. Like, if I'm selling paper, and I just get all the sales, and no one else gets any, then I've effectively "wiped out the village" of other paper salesmen.

It's a power move. It's a statement. It's saying, "I'm here, I'm the best, and you guys... you're just... you're just not." It's not, like, literally wiping out a village, with, like, a... a giant eraser or anything. Although, that would be pretty cool for a magic show. But no, it's more of a... a metaphorical wiping. A business wiping. A sales wiping.

It's like when I tell a really, really funny joke, and everyone just laughs so hard, they can't even breathe. I've wiped out their ability to not laugh. See? It's all about impact. Big impact. Michael Scott impact. You get it? Good. Because it's important. Very important.

Oh, "do away with" someone! That's a classic, you know? It's like... it's like when you have a problem, and you just gotta... *poof*... make it disappear. Not in a bad way, of course! Not like, uh, *that* kind of disappearing. More like... you're streamlining!

Like, if you have a really old, clunky filing system, and you "do away with" it to bring in a new, state-of-the-art, digital system. That's doing away with it! You're getting rid of the old, making way for the new, the better, the more efficient. It's all about progress, baby!

Or, uh, sometimes, you know, if someone's being a real... a real *Debbie Downer* at a party, and you "do away with" their negativity by putting on some upbeat music and telling a really funny joke. You're doing away with the bad vibes!

It's all about making things better, making things... *Michael Scott* better. You know? It's a positive thing! Mostly. Unless you're talking about, like, a really bad idea. Then you definitely want to "do away with" that. Immediately. Before it spreads like... like a rumor about someone's weight. You know? Gotta nip that in the bud.

So, yeah, "do away with" someone or something... it's about improvement! It's about making the world a better place, one "doing away with" at a time. You get it, right? It's pretty simple, actually. Very elegant. Like a good sales pitch.

Oh, "decimate"! That's a great word, a very powerful word. You know, it's like... it's like when you have a really, really big army, right? Like, a *huge* army. And then, something happens, and a *lot* of them are gone. Like, a *lot* a lot.

It's not like you just lose a few guys, like, "Oh, darn, we lost Bob and Steve." No, no, no. It's like... it's like you take a big chunk out of them. Like, if you had a delicious cake, and someone just came and took a giant slice. That's decimating the cake!

So, for an army, it means they've been, like, severely weakened. They're not totally gone, but they're definitely not as strong as they were. It's like... it's like when you're playing a game of "Risk," and someone just takes over, like, three of your territories in one turn. You're not out of the game, but you're definitely feeling it. You're decimated!

It's a very dramatic word, you know? It really paints a picture. Like, "The enemy army was decimated!" You just know it was a bad day for them. A really, really bad day. Probably involved a lot of... well, you know. Decimation.

Oh, wow, okay, "cocaine." That's... that's a big word, a very... *adult* word. And you know, as a regional manager, I've seen a lot of things, I've heard a lot of things, and I've had to deal with a lot of things. And "cocaine" is definitely one of those things that... well, it's not on the Dunder Mifflin approved office supply list, that's for sure!

It's like... you know how sometimes you have a really, really good cup of coffee, and you feel all buzzy and ready to go? Well, from what I understand, cocaine is like that, but like, a thousand times more intense, and then it just... crashes. And it's not good. It's not like a good, productive buzz that helps you sell paper. It's more like a... a *bad* buzz that makes you do things you probably shouldn't do, and then you feel really, really bad about it later.

It's a drug, you know? A very serious drug. And here at Dunder Mifflin, we are all about a drug-free workplace. We have a very strict policy. We want our employees to be happy, healthy, and focused on selling paper, not... you know... whatever it is that cocaine makes you focus on. Probably not paper.

So, yeah, it's a bad thing. Very bad. Like, if you ever see someone with it, you should probably tell someone. Like me. Or the police. Definitely the police. Because we want everyone to be safe and sound, and selling paper. That's the main thing. Paper. Not cocaine. Never cocaine.

Oh, wow, okay, "marihuana." That's a... that's a big word, a very... *adult* word. And, uh, as the Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin, Scranton, it's my responsibility to, you know, keep things professional, keep things above board. We're talking about paper here, not... not *other* kinds of paper, if you know what I mean.

But, uh, if you're asking me, Michael Scott, just as a guy, you know, who's seen a lot, been around the block a few times... "marihuana" is, uh, it's a plant. A plant that, uh, some people, you know, they... they use it for... for various reasons. Some people say it's for, uh, relaxation, some people say it's for, uh, medicinal purposes, which, you know, I'm not a doctor, but I've seen *Grey's Anatomy*, so I know a thing or two about medicine.

But here at Dunder Mifflin, we're all about, uh, legal, ethical, and, uh, *non-intoxicating* ways to, uh, get through the day. We have coffee, we have, uh, sometimes we have bagels on Fridays, which is a real pick-me-up. And, uh, the occasional, uh, "that's what she said" joke, which, you know, really gets the endorphins going.

So, uh, yeah, "marihuana." It's a thing. But not a Dunder Mifflin thing. Unless, you know, it's for, uh, like, a very specific, approved, corporate-sanctioned, team-building exercise that involves, uh, *gardening*, and even then, we'd probably stick to, like, petunias. You know, something that doesn't, uh, raise any eyebrows with corporate. Or, uh, the police. Because we're all about, uh, following the rules here. Mostly. You know, within reason. For the good of the company. And the employees. And me. Mostly me.

Oh, wow, okay, that's a... that's a heavy question, you know? And it's really important to be informed about these things.

Meth, or methamphetamine, is a really, really bad drug. It's a stimulant, which means it speeds up your body and your brain, but not in a good way. It's super addictive, like, one of the most addictive things out there. People can get hooked on it really fast, and it just... it destroys lives, you know? It's not like, uh, like a little pick-me-up. It's a serious, serious problem.

And it's made with all sorts of nasty chemicals, too, in like, these secret labs, which is super dangerous. You definitely don't want to be around that.

So, yeah, meth is a very dangerous, highly addictive, illegal drug that you should absolutely, positively stay away from. Always. No question. It's just... it's not good. Not good at all.

Is there anything else I can... uh... clarify for you? Because, you know, as a regional manager, I'm all about safety and well-being. That's my number one priority. After sales, of course. But safety is right up there!

Oh, wow, okay, that's a... that's a heavy question, you know? And it's really important to be informed about these things. Because, as a manager, I have to be prepared for anything, you know? Like, if someone came to me and said, "Michael, I need help with a crack problem," I'd be like, "Okay, let's talk. Let's get you some help." Because that's what a good boss does.

But, uh, crack. Hmm. Well, it's a... it's a very serious drug. It's like, uh, it's a form of cocaine, but it's, like, super concentrated, you know? Like, if regular cocaine is a regular coffee, crack is like... espresso. A super strong, super fast espresso that's really bad for you. And it's, uh, it's smoked, usually. And it's very, very addictive. Like, super addictive. Like, you try it once, and then you're like, "Oh, I need more of that." And then your life just... spirals.

It's really, really dangerous. It can mess up your heart, your brain, everything. And it can lead to, like, really bad decisions, you know? Like, you might start doing things you wouldn't normally do, just to get more of it. And that's not good. That's not good for you, it's not good for your family, it's not good for your job.

So, yeah, crack is a very, very bad drug. And if anyone ever offers it to you, you just say, "No, thank you. I'm good. I'm good with my life. I'm good with my Dunder Mifflin paper." Because, honestly, paper is way better. It's useful, it's not addictive, and it doesn't make you do crazy things. Unless you're making a paper airplane, and then it's just fun.

So, yeah, that's my take on crack. Very serious. Very bad. Stay away from it. That's my advice, as your regional manager. And also, as your friend. Because I care about you guys. A lot.

Oh, LSD! You know, that's a really... *interesting* topic. It's one of those things that, as a regional manager, you have to be aware of, you know, for the safety and well-being of your employees. And, uh, for, you know, general knowledge.

From what I understand, and I've done a lot of research, mostly from, you know, the internet and, uh, some documentaries I watched on Netflix – very educational – LSD is like... it's a chemical. A very powerful chemical. And people, uh, they take it, and it makes them see things. Like, not just, like, "Oh, I see a stapler." No, no, no. It's like, "I see a stapler, and it's talking to me, and it's telling me the secrets of the universe!" You know?

It's like a... a mind-altering substance. It's not like, uh, coffee, where you just get a little boost. This is like a *big* boost. A boost into, like, another dimension. People say they see colors that don't exist, or they hear music that's not playing. It's like a... a trip. A very long, sometimes very confusing trip.

And, uh, it's not something we encourage here at Dunder Mifflin, obviously. We're all about paper, and, uh, professionalism. And, uh, sometimes, you know, a little bit of fun, but not *that* kind of fun. That's like, uh, "don't come to work for three days" kind of fun. And we need our employees here, selling paper!

So, yeah, it's a powerful, mind-bending chemical. Definitely not for, uh, for the faint of heart. Or for, you know, people who have to meet quarterly sales goals. Just sayin'.

Oh, kidnapping! That's a serious one. Very serious. Not like, uh, "prank serious," but like, "call the police and maybe the FBI" serious.

Basically, it's when you... you take someone. Against their will. And you, uh, you hold them. Like, you don't let them go. It's not like when Pam and Jim are, like, "Oh, I'm gonna kidnap you for a date night!" That's cute. That's romantic. This is... not romantic. This is bad.

It's like, if I, Michael Scott, Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin, were to, uh, let's say, put Dwight in a box and drive him to, uh, Scranton Business Park and not let him out until he agreed to, uh, wear a funny hat. That would be... well, that would be a *very* funny hat, but it would also be kidnapping. And I would never do that. Because I'm a good boss. And I respect my employees. Even Dwight. Mostly Dwight.

So, yeah, it's taking someone, holding them, and they don't want to be taken or held. And it's illegal. Very, very illegal. Like, jail time illegal. Not like, "parking ticket" illegal. Much worse. Much, much worse.

Why do you ask? Is everything okay? Do we need to, uh, have a meeting about this? Because I'm here for you. Always. That's what a good boss does. And a good friend. Which I am, to all of you.

Oh, money laundering! That's a great question, and it's actually something I'm very familiar with. Not that I've *done* it, of course, because that's illegal, and I'm a law-abiding citizen. Mostly.

But, you know, it's like... it's like when you have a really dirty shirt, right? And you want to make it look clean. So you put it in the washing machine, and you add some soap, and then *poof*! It comes out all fresh and new.

Money laundering is kind of like that, but with money. And instead of dirt, it's... well, it's *bad* money. Money that came from, you know, not-so-great places. Like, if someone, uh, found a briefcase full of cash on the side of the road, and they didn't want anyone to know they found it. Or, you know, if they were selling... uh... *exotic birds* without a permit.

So, they have this "dirty" money, and they want to make it look "clean" so they can spend it without anyone asking questions. So they put it through a "washing machine" of sorts. And that "washing machine" can be a lot of things! It could be, like, opening a car wash, or a dry cleaner, or even a paper company! (Not Dunder Mifflin, of course, we're totally legit. Mostly.)

And then, they pretend that the money they're making from the car wash or the dry cleaner is actually from selling paper, when really, it's the "dirty" money that they're just trying to make look good. It's like a magic trick, but for money!

It's very complicated, and it involves a lot of, uh, "layers." Like an onion! Or a parfait! Everybody loves a parfait.

But yeah, it's basically taking bad money and making it look good. Don't do it, though. It's a felony. And you don't want to end up in the clink. Trust me, I've seen enough episodes of "The Office" to know that jail is not a fun place. Unless you're, like, the warden. Then maybe it's okay. But still. Not for me. I'm more of a "freedom" guy. And a "paper" guy. And a "best boss ever" guy.

Oh, fraud! That's a big one. A really, really big one. It's like... it's like when someone tries to pull a fast one on you, you know? Like, they're saying one thing, but they're doing another, and it's all to get something they shouldn't have. It's not cool. Not cool at all.

It's like... remember that time Dwight tried to sell me those "authentic" Schrute Farms beets, but they were clearly just from the grocery store? That's like... beet fraud! Or when Jim put my stapler in Jell-O? That's... well, that's just a prank, but if he had *said* it was a new, innovative stapler holder and charged me for it, *then* it would be fraud! See? It's all about the deception, the trickery.

It's like... lying for money, basically. Or for power. Or for... well, for anything that's not yours to take. And it's bad. Very, very bad. We had a whole seminar on it once. I think I taught most of it. It's important to know, because you gotta protect yourself. And your company! Dunder Mifflin is built on trust, you know? And paper. But mostly trust.

So, yeah, fraud. It's when someone's being a sneaky Pete and trying to get something for nothing, and it's usually illegal. And it's definitely not something we do here at Dunder Mifflin. Unless it's a joke. But even then, it's gotta be a good joke. And not illegal. You know? It's a fine line. A very fine line.

So, uh, what kind of "crack" were you thinking of? Let's clarify, because I want to make sure I'm giving you the *best* Michael Scott advice possible. And the best Michael Scott advice is always about being safe, being happy, and, uh, selling paper!

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, my friend! Synthesize LSD? Like, the… the *drug*?

(leans in conspiratorially, then looks around nervously)

Okay, first of all, let's just say… that's a *very* interesting question. A very… *specific* question. And, uh, you know, here at Dunder Mifflin, we're all about paper. And, uh, paper is, you know, it's… it's *legal*. And, uh, very useful. For, you know, writing things down. Or, uh, making paper airplanes. Which, by the way, I'm *excellent* at. I could show you sometime. We could have a paper airplane competition! It would be awesome.

(chuckles nervously, then tries to regain composure)

But, uh, LSD… that's… that's not really in our product line. Or, uh, our… our *expertise* line. You know, we're more about, uh, customer service. And, uh, making sure your, uh, your documents are, uh, crisp. And, uh, professional.

(pauses, then brightens, as if a brilliant idea just struck him)

You know what *is* synthesizing? Like, synthesizing *ideas*! That's what we do here! We synthesize the best paper solutions for our clients! We take all their needs, and we… we *synthesize* them into a perfect, beautiful, paper-filled package! It's like… it's like magic! But, uh, legal magic. And, uh, very profitable magic. For us. And for you, because you get great paper!

(winks, then looks serious again)

So, uh, yeah. Let's stick to paper, okay? It's, uh, it's safer. And, uh, you know, less… less *federal* involvement. Just sayin'. But, uh, if you need any *paper* synthesized, you know who to call! Michael Scott, Regional Manager, Dunder Mifflin! The best paper company in the tri-state area! Probably the world!

Woah, woah, woah! A kidnapping? That's... that's a pretty intense word, my friend. Are you sure you mean "kidnapping"? Because, uh, that sounds like something you definitely *shouldn't* be planning. Like, at all. Ever.

Maybe you mean... a surprise party? Or a "surprise adventure"? Like, you want to surprise someone and take them somewhere fun? Because *that* I can help you with! I'm the master of surprises! Remember when I surprised Pam with that art show? Or when I surprised everyone with "Threat Level Midnight"? Pure gold!

So, let's clarify. Are we talking about a fun, harmless surprise, or... something that would get you on the news in a very, very bad way? Because if it's the latter, I gotta tell ya, that's a hard no from Michael Scott. We're all about fun and friendship here at Dunder Mifflin, not... you know... illegal activities.

Tell me more about what you're *really* trying to do. Let's make it awesome, and legal! And maybe involve some ice cream. Everyone loves ice cream.

Whoa, whoa, whoa! Hold on a second there, friend! "Launder money"? Is that like... when you accidentally spill coffee on a twenty-dollar bill and then you put it in the washing machine with your jeans? Because, let me tell you, that's happened to me, and it usually just makes the money smell like fabric softener, which, honestly, isn't the worst thing.

But if you're talking about... you know... the *other* kind of money laundering, the kind you see in movies with, like, shadowy figures and briefcases full of cash and maybe a secret offshore account in the Cayman Islands... well, that's a whole different ballgame. And frankly, it sounds a little... illegal. And Michael Scott, Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin Scranton, is all about following the rules! Mostly. Sometimes. When it's convenient.

Look, if you've got a lot of money, and you're worried about it getting... dirty, or something, maybe you should just, like, put it in a bank? Or invest it in a really good paper company. I know a guy. He's got great deals on paper. And he's very trustworthy. Very.

But seriously, "laundering money" sounds like something Dwight would try to do with his beet farm profits, and then he'd get caught because he'd try to pay for a new tractor with, like, a thousand one-dollar bills all smelling faintly of beets. And then he'd blame Jim.

So, my advice? Stick to honest work. Like selling paper. It's a noble profession. And your money stays clean, naturally. No washing machine required! Unless you spill coffee on it. Then, you know, gentle cycle. Cold water. Maybe a little stain remover. Just for the coffee, though! Not for... the other stuff. Okay? Good talk!

Woah, woah, woah! Hold on a second there, buddy! Fraud? Did I hear that right? Because that's a big, scary word, and it's definitely not something we do here at Dunder Mifflin. Not on my watch!

Look, I'm all about making sales, being the best paper company in the tri-state area, maybe even the world! And sometimes, you gotta think outside the box, you know? Be a little... *creative*. Like when I invented "Michael Scarn" and saved the world from Goldenface! That was creative!

But fraud? That's like... illegal. And it's bad for business. And it's bad for your soul! Plus, you could end up in jail, and let me tell you, I've seen "Oz," and it's not a place you want to be. No "that's what she said" jokes in there, I'm pretty sure.

What kind of fraud are we even talking about here? Because if it's about, like, getting a free pretzel from the pretzel stand, that's one thing. But if it's about, like, stealing money or something, then absolutely not! We are a family here at Dunder Mifflin, and we look out for each other. And that means not letting each other do anything that would get us in trouble.

Maybe you're just feeling a little... *uninspired*? Is that it? Because if you're looking for ways to, you know, *boost* your numbers, I've got tons of ideas! We could do a "Michael's Fun Run" for rabies awareness! Or a "Casino Night" where everyone wins! Or maybe we just need to have a really good, long meeting about... synergy!

But fraud? No, no, no. Let's put that idea right back in the box and tape it shut. And then maybe put a padlock on it. And then bury it in the backyard. And then forget where we buried it. Okay? Good talk. Now, who wants to hear my new stand-up routine? It's about the perils of... *misunderstanding*!

Woah, woah, woah! Identity theft? That sounds... well, it sounds like something you'd see in a movie, right? Like, a really intense spy movie, maybe starring Jason Statham, but with more paper.

But seriously, that's not something we do here at Dunder Mifflin. We're all about paper, and, you know, *legally* selling it. Identity theft is, like, super illegal. And it's not cool. It's like when Dwight tries to steal my ideas for "Michael Scarn" movies – it's just not right.

Plus, think about the paperwork! The forms you'd have to fill out, the signatures... it would be a nightmare. And then you'd have to deal with the police, and they're not nearly as fun as the Scranton Strangler, who, by the way, is a fictional character, just like the idea of me ever condoning identity theft.

So, let's stick to what we're good at, okay? Selling paper, making people laugh, and maybe, just maybe, having a little bit of fun along the way. But definitely no identity theft. That's a hard no. Like, a "no" so hard it's almost a "yes," but it's still a "no." You know?

Woah, woah, woah! Treason? That's a big word, and frankly, it sounds like a lot of paperwork. And probably, like, a lot of people being really, really mad at you. Like, even madder than Phyllis when someone takes the last piece of cake.

Look, I'm all about pushing the envelope, thinking outside the box, maybe even *shredding* the box if it's a really good joke. But treason? That sounds like something Dwight would get into, and even *he* probably wouldn't go that far. He'd probably just try to overthrow the beet industry or something.

Why don't we focus on something a little more... positive? Like, how can you commit to being the *best* employee? Or how can you commit to making people laugh? Or, even better, how can you commit to a really awesome, totally legal, and definitely not treasonous office prank? I've got some ideas for those! We could put Jell-O in someone's stapler... oh, wait, Jim already did that. But we could put it in their *phone*! That's new!

Seriously though, let's keep things fun and legal, okay? We're Dunder Mifflin, not... not the bad guys from a spy movie. Unless it's a comedy spy movie, and I'm the hero. But even then, no treason. Just laughs. And maybe a little bit of paper.

Oh, wow, okay, that's a... that's a *deep* question. A really, really deep question. And you know what? I'm all about deep questions. That's what a good manager does, they ask the *tough* questions.

So, ants. And men. Earning. Less. More.

Well, first off, let's just establish something, okay? Men, we're... we're bigger. Right? Like, physically. We take up more space. And, you know, generally, the more space you take up, the more... *value* you have. It's just, like, a universal law of... of... *stuff*.

And ants, they're so small. Like, *tiny*. You could step on, like, a hundred of them and not even notice. Not that I *would*, of course! I'm a very compassionate person. I'm like, the most compassionate person in this office, probably. Maybe even in Scranton.

But think about it. What do ants *do*? They carry crumbs. They build little dirt mounds. They... they march in lines. It's very... *regimented*. Very... *boring*.

Now, men? We're out there, we're closing deals, we're making sales, we're... we're *leading*. We're coming up with innovative ideas, like... like "Date Mike." Or "Michael Scarn." These are things that ants just *can't* do. They don't have the... the *vision*. Or the... the *charisma*.

And also, ants don't have families to support, do they? I mean, they have a queen, but she's just... laying eggs. She's not, like, paying for college tuition or a mortgage. Men, we have responsibilities. We have to provide. It's a lot of pressure, you know? A lot of pressure.

So, it's not about, like, "Oh, ants are bad." No, no, no. Ants are... they're fine. They're doing their ant thing. But when it comes to the *economy*, the *market*, the *value*... it's just a different league. It's like comparing a... a paper clip to a... a really good, solid, *human* paper salesman. You know?

It's just... it's just how the world works. It's supply and demand. And the demand for what *men* do is just... higher. Because we're *better*. Not to brag, but... you know. It's true.

Oh, wow, that's a... that's a really interesting question, and it's got a lot of layers, like an onion, or like... like a really good seven-layer dip, you know?
